assessment_comment: The culvert is undersized for current flow volumes, as indicated by a very large 1.15m outlet drop. Habitat confirmation was completed upstream, downstream, and below Gala Bay Road.
condition_notes: Severe erosion at the outlet has caused significant downcutting and a large outlet pool. Overall, the culvert and road prism are in good condition.
climate_notes: The culvert appears undersized, as indicated by the large outlet drop and outlet pool. Downstream, recreational properties, small cabins, and an unpaved road could be impacted by a blowout.

assessment_comments_og: The culvert is undersized for current flow volumes, as indicated by a very large 1.15m outlet drop. Habitat confirmation was completed upstream, downstream, and below Gala Bay Road.

assessment_comment: The local name of the stream is Burnt Cabin Creek. It had a large outlet drop and a heavily eroded outlet pool, indicating the culvert was undersized. The stream provided complex habitat for fish with abundant cover. The low-traffic dirt road had minimal road fill, making construction relatively straightforward.
condition_notes: The culvert was in good condition. There was severe erosion under the outlet of the pipe, indicating it was significantly undersized for the stream.
climate_notes: The culvert was significantly undersized for the stream. A flood could likely wash out the road due to minimal road fill.

assessment_comments_og: Local name of stream is Burnt Cabin Creek. Nice dream with a huge outlet drop. Outlet pool is quite big and eroded indicating the culvert is under size for the size of the stream. Low traffic dirt road with not much Phil, so construction would be relatively easy.

assessment_comment: The culvert was very undersized for the stream, as evidenced by the large outlet drop. The stream had a good amount of flow for the time of year. Habitat was of medium value, with abundant large woody debris creating complex habitat and pools, providing ample cover for fish. Adjacent landowners reported that the stream was previously used as a water source for bottling and distribution across the province. Habitat confirmation was completed upstream and downstream.
condition_notes: The pipe was significantly bent left to right along the bottom two-thirds, with the upper side bent upward for the top 6m. There was extensive erosion at the old outlet, with a very large outlet drop, indicating the culvert was severely undersized for the stream.
climate_notes: The large outlet drop indicated that the pipe was undersized for the stream and may not accommodate major runoff or precipitation events. Downstream, recreational residences could be affected.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Good amount of flow for this time of year. Adjacent landowners report that this stream was previously used as a source of water that was bottled and distributed throughout the province. Culvert is likely very undersized as evidenced by the large outlet drop.     Habitat confirmation assessment completed upstream and downstream

assessment_comment: Two fully embedded PVC pipes, each 0.7m in diameter. One pipe was completely backwatered. Medium-value habitat was observed, with extensive gravels suitable for spawning upstream and downstream. A historic Chinook spawning point was recorded adjacent to the road. Habitat confirmations were conducted upstream, downstream, and above Stella Road.
condition_notes: Relatively new structures, in good condition with no evidence of issues at the road.
climate_notes: The significant embedment suggested that over time, the pipes could become clogged, potentially requiring maintenance to prevent a road washout.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Two fully embedded PVC pipes at 0.7 m each. One of the pipes is 100% back watered. Extensive gravel, upstream and downstream with historic Chinnook point recorded adjacent to the road.

assessment_comment: Two pipes, 0.6m and 0.45m in diameter, were present. There was a 0.7m outlet drop, and only the larger pipe conveyed flow. The inlet side of the road had completely eroded into the stream, obstructing the view of the inlet. No light was visible through the culverts from the outlet side, though water was still flowing. A landowner had placed a barricade across the road, likely to prevent access due to severe erosion of the road. The stream provided high-quality habitat with abundant large woody debris creating pools and gravels suitable for spawning. Just downstream, a functioning water intake shack was located in the middle of the stream, likely supplying the adjacent landowner’s property. Plastic pipes extended from the intake shack downstream to the lower Stella Road crossing. The heavily overgrown and collapsing road appeared to be private access and would be a good candidate for removal. Due to inlet erosion, culvert length and slope were estimated as the inlet could not be located.
condition_notes: The roadbed had completely eroded into the stream on the inlet side, fully blocking the view of the inlet. The heavily overgrown and collapsing road appeared to be private access and would be a good candidate for removal.
climate_notes: A flood would likely wash out the road due to the inlet being obstructed by erosion debris.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Two pipes, one at 0.6 and one at 0.45 m in diameter. Decent outlet drop and water is only flowing through the bigger of the two pipes. The road on the inlet side has completely eroded into the stream visibly blocking The view of the inlet. Cannot see any light at the end of the culverts from the outlet side, but water is able to flow still. Landowner has put a barricade across the road likely to stop people because the road is so eroded. Nice with really good habitat, lots of large wood debris, creating pools. Gravel present and suitable for spawning fish. Just downstream of the culvert is a water intake shack located in the middle of the stream that was heard functioning during the time of survey. Likely used by the adjacent landowners whose house you can see from the stream. Plastic pipes also seen in the stream from the water intake shack down to the lower crossing on Stella Road. Road seems very overgrown and doesn’t really lead to anywhere so would be a good candidate for removing the road. Culvert length and slope estimated because I could not locate the inlet of the pipes due to erosion of road.

assessment_comment: The inlets of both culverts were dammed by a beaver, backing up water to most of the culverts' height. Two pipes, each 1.6m in diameter, were present. A large outlet pool indicated the pipes were likely undersized for the stream. Another beaver dam was being constructed at the outlet of the pool. The dirt road had minimal road fill, making construction relatively straightforward. The road appeared to be used for pipeline access. Outlet pool depth was estimated as it was too deep to wade. Fish approximately 40mm in length were observed downstream during habitat confirmation.
condition_notes: Erosion was present under the outlet of the pipes. Both pipes were blocked by beaver dams, with only 10–25% of the culvert visible from the inlet side.
climate_notes: The large outlet pool suggested the pipes are likely undersized for the stream. The beaver dam blockage inside the pipes restricted flow, which could have increased the risk of a road washout during a flood.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Inlet’s of both culverts are damned inside by the beaver backing up the water to most of the height of the culvert. Two pipes at 1.6 m in diameter. Each. Massive outlet pool, indicating the size of the pipes are likely undersized for the size of the stream. Another beaver dam being constructed at the outlet of the outlet pool. Not much fail and dirt Road so construction would be fairly easy. I believe the road is used for pipeline use. Outlet pool depth estimated because too deep to wade into. Fish observed during habitat, confirmation downstream roughly 40 mm in length

assessment_comment: The bottom of the culvert had been reinforced with concrete, likely to address holes noted in the previous assessment. A large pile of riprap was placed at the outlet, possibly to reduce the outlet drop, though its placement appeared unusual and could inhibit fish passage. The habitat was high quality, with a large pool just downstream of the culvert and abundant gravels suitable for spawning fish.
condition_notes: The culvert was in good condition, with the bottom recently reinforced with concrete. No erosion or blockage issues were observed.
climate_notes: The culvert was very large, and the size of the outlet pool suggests the stream experiences high flows at certain times of the year. A flood would be unlikely to affect the culvert, but if it did, it could wash out the highway.

assessment_comments_og: Bottom of culvert has been reinforced with concrete, supposedly to fix the holes mentioned in the previous assessment. Outlet of culvert has a huge pile of rip wrap perhaps to reduce the lead drop but seems a bit odd and perhaps might inhibit fish passage. really nice habitat, nice big pool just downstream of the culvert and lots of gravel present for spawning fish.

assessment_comment: The bridge crosses Clear Creek and appeared to provide access to private land.

assessment_comment: Two pipes, each 2.8m in diameter, were present. The pipe on the north side was not flowing. The gradient directly downstream of the culvert was 3–4% due to boulders placed to create backwatering, which was somewhat functioning, though the culverts were not fully backwatered, but water levels were elevated. The rest of the stream had a gradient of 0.5%. The stream provided good habitat but was fairly channelized due to residential development on both sides. Signs of high flows were evident, with eroding banks. Few pools and limited functional large woody debris were present.
condition_notes: No blockage or road fill issues were observed. There appeared to be erosion under the outlet of the north pipe, which had been reinforced with a foam-like substance. See photos for details.
climate_notes: The culverts were large, with only one conveying flow. A flood would likely not affect the culverts, but as a highway crossing, the consequences of failure would be high.
priority_notes: Highway crossing so construction would be expensive and difficult. Known  chinnook point on stream.

assessment_comments_og: Two pipes at 2.8 m in diameter each. Pipe on the north side is not flowing. Gradient directly below, the culvert are 3 to 4% due to boulders being placed to create back watering, which is somewhat functioning, but the culverts are not back watered, but the water is definitely higher. The rest of the stream has a gradient of 0.5%. Nice dream with good habitat, fairly channelized due to it running due to residence on both sides,. Stream show signs of high flows with eroding banks. Not many pools or functional large debris.

assessment_comment: The culvert was fully backwatered, with the outlet completely submerged. The stream flowed through a grassy valley on private property upstream. The road column on the inlet side was eroding significantly. A V-shaped fence was positioned in front of the inlet for unknown reasons. Culvert slope and length were estimated, as the inlet was completely submerged and not visible. The culvert was embedded at the inlet and assumed to be fully embedded, though this could not be confirmed due to the submerged outlet. Just upstream of the inlet, remnants of a possible old dam were observed, with large piles of dirt on both sides and a dugout middle section allowing stream flow. See photos for details.
condition_notes: The road column on the inlet side was completely eroding. There was 6–7m of road fill. The culvert was fully backwatered but remained passable.
climate_notes: There was a significant amount of road fill over the culvert, so a flood would not affect the road. The road column was already eroding on the right side.
priority_notes: Country paved road with lots of fill so construction would be expensive. stream flows into beaverley creek, which is a known fish brain stream. So construction could have environmental impacts.

assessment_comments_og: Culvert is fully back, watered with the outlet completely submerged. Stream flows through grassy Valley on someone’s property upstream. Road column on inlet side is eroding significantly. Fence positioned in front of the inlet in V shape, not sure why. Calvert slope and length estimated Due to the inlet being completely submerged and basically not visible.  Culvert is embedded at the inlet and assuming full embedment, but cannot confirm due to outlet being completely submerged.  Just upstream of inlet is the remnants of perhaps an old damn, big piles of dirt on each side. Now it has the middle dugout to allow the stream to flow down. See photos.

assessment_comment: This was an overflow pipe for PSCIS crossing 199255, located 60m south. It may have been present and dry in 2023 when PSCIS crossing 199255 was initially assessed, but this is uncertain. Habitat confirmations were conducted upstream and downstream. Upstream habitat was a low-gradient gravel system with mature riparian vegetation and stable banks.

assessment_comments_og: This is an overflow pipe for the crossing inventory, just 60 m south. May have been here last year and dry, but not sure.  Habitat confirmation conducted. Upstream is low gradient gravel system with mature rep Ryan and state banks.

assessment_comment: Large multi-plate oval culvert with a substantial 50m-wide outlet pool. Chinook, bull trout, and other species are documented upstream in the FISS database. The stream had high flow at the time of assessment. Culvert slope and outlet pool depth were estimated as the pool was too deep to wade. Deep pools over 1m, formed by functional large woody debris, provided good overwintering habitat for fish of all ages. Gravels suitable for spawning were present. Downstream of the culvert, the stream ran parallel to the highway with banks reinforced by riprap and large wood secured with metal wiring to create habitat and reduce flow.
condition_notes: Erosion was present under the outlet of the pipe. Embankment fill erosion was observed on the left side of the outlet. No blockage issues were present.
climate_notes: Large culvert and outlet pool indicated the stream experienced high flows. Flow was high at the time of assessment, and the pipe was functioning well. A flood would be unlikely to affect the culvert, but if it did, it could wash out Highway 16.
priority_notes: Highway crossing so construction would be expensive and difficult. Known fish, bearing stream and signs at the outlet indicating this is a spawning area so environmental impacts could be high
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Multi plate round culvert. Call Vert slope estimated. Massive culvert with an even bigger outlet pool probably 50 m wide. Stream was just pumping during time of survey. Outlet pool depth estimated because pool was too deep to wait into.

assessment_comment: The culvert had a significant 1.4m outlet drop, and inlet drop due to a small debris jam. The stream flowed through mature old-growth forest and provided high-quality habitat with steep gradients, step pools, and cascade pools, suggesting the potential presence of bull trout. The highway crossing had a large amount of road fill, making construction difficult and expensive. The site would be a good candidate for replacement if feasible. The riparian area at the outlet had been cleared due to overhead powerlines.
condition_notes: The outlet of the pipe was perched, with significant erosion under the left side. A small debris jam at the inlet created an inlet drop, but no other blockages were present. The embankment fill was in good condition.
climate_notes: The size of the outlet pool suggested the culvert was significantly undersized for the stream. A flood would likely impact the culvert, potentially causing significant damage as it was located under Highway 16.
priority_notes: Highway crossing so expensive and difficult. Likely a fish bearing stream with lots of of nice gravel, likely bull trout in the system given the steepness of the stream. Environmental impact could be quite high due to construction.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Inlet drop due to small debris jam at Inlet. Highway crossing with a large amount of fill therefore construction will be difficult and expensive. But there’s a massive outlet drop and the stream has lots of nice gravel and a steep grade, likely bull trout in the system. Would be a great candidate for a placement if possible. Repairing area outlet has been cleared due to powerlines overhead.

assessment_comment: The inlet of the culvert was completely submerged, with a large beaver pond area just upstream. The outlet was plugged with beaver sticks, and it appeared the beaver had dammed the culvert entirely, creating a large pool at the inlet. Despite this, the culvert still had flow. A beaver dam approximately 0.7m in height was located about 40m downstream. A new culvert had been installed 60m north on the FSR, with flow from that crossing entering the outlet pool from the north. Downstream of the culvert, the stream flowed through the forest with minimal defined channel. Where a defined channel was present, it ranged from 1–3m wide, but most of the area consisted of 15–17m of wetted forest with some flow. Culvert slope was estimated due to the submerged inlet. Habitat confirmations were conducted upstream and downstream.
condition_notes: Fever has plugged up the culvert, with lots of debris sticking out the outlet, culvert is jammed all the way through and creating a big pool at the inlet, with the inlet completely submerged
climate_notes: Call Culver is quite small for the size of the stream, due to the beaver damming up the culvert, likely that a flood would wash out the road as there’s only a metre and a half of sale on top of the culvert.
priority_notes: The road FSR with not much sales so construction would be relatively easy and expensive. This is a trip to kenneth creek, which is a fish bearing stream so they like the fish in the system, therefore there could be environment impacts.

assessment_comments_og: Inlet of culvert, completely submerged, with big beaver pond area just upstream. Outlet of culvert plugwg up with beaver sticks, it looks like the beaver has damed it all the way through to create big pool at inlet. Culvert still has flow though. There is a beaver dam roughly 0.7m in height about 40m downstream of the culvert. There has been a new culvert installed that is 40 m north on the FSR, so flow from that crossing is entering the outlet pool from the north. Downstream of the culvert the stream flows through the forest with very little areas with define channel. Where there is a fine channel it’s roughly 1-3m wide, but most of the time it’s just 15-17m of wetted forrest with some flow. Culvert slope estimated due to submerged inlet.

assessment_comment: The culvert had a deep outlet pool and a very large outlet drop. The stream was banked with a well-developed, healthy, riparian zone consisting of old-growth forest. A beaver dam was located just upstream of the culvert inlet. No photos are available because the surveyors phone fell into the stream.

assessment_comment: At the time of assessment, the stream was dry at the crossing; however, it contained medium-value habitat. Upstream of the culvert, the stream was primarily dry for the first 300m, then intermittent pools began to appear, associated with beaver activity. Approximately 450–500m upstream, the stream became nearly fully watered, with pools up to 40cm deep. Downstream of the crossing was dominated by beaver-impounded wetland areas, which were storing large quantities of water, likely sustaining year-round stream flow at the downstream crossing on Dog Creek Road. Further downstream, approximately 300m upstream of the crossing on Dog Creek Road, the stream transitioned to a channelized system with some pockets of gravel suitable for rearing rainbow trout and potentially Chinook. However, heavy cattle impacts were observed at both this crossing and the downstream crossing on Dog Creek Road.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Stream was dry at the time of assessment.

assessment_comment: The culvert had a moderate outlet drop with some erosion around the pipe at the outlet. The pipe was in good condition. The stream provided excellent habitat, with several pools and abundant undercut banks. Fish were observed during the assessment (~40–90mm in length). Upstream of the crossing, the stream was channelized with some pockets of gravel suitable for rearing rainbow trout and potentially Chinook. It then transitioned into beaver-impounded wetland areas storing large quantities of water, likely sustaining year-round stream flow at this crossing. There was extensive cattle trampling around the inlet of the pipe and throughout the surveyed upstream area. The crossing was located approximately 150m upstream from the Nechako River mainstem.

assessment_comments_og: The culvert had a moderate outlet drop with some erosion around the pipe at the outlet. The stream provided excellent habitat, with several pools and abundant undercut banks. Fish were observed during the assessment (~40–90 mm in length). The pipe was in good condition, though signs of cattle trampling were present at the inlet. The crossing is located approximately 150 m upstream from the Nechako River mainstem.

assessment_comment: A significant outlet drop was present. Flow was high at the time of assessment, and at lower flows, the outlet drop would be even more substantial. Although the culvert was large, it was still likely undersized for the stream. The stream was a large glaciated system with a cobble-boulder substrate and an intact mixed riparian zone, primarily deciduous. Occasional large woody debris features created deep pool habitats and pockets of gravels were present suitable for spawning salmonids.  A fish (~60mm) was observed during habitat confirmation.
condition_notes: No blockage issues were present. Embankment fill erosion was observed on both sides of the culvert outlet.
climate_notes: Although the pipe was large, it was still undersized for the stream and could wash out in a flood. As a highway crossing with only 2m of road fill, a flood could wash out the highway.
priority_notes: Likely a nice bull trout stream so there could be environment impacts due to construction. Highway crossing so expensive and difficult to fix.

assessment_comments_og: Although culver it big it is still likely undersized for the size of the stream. Lots of flow at time of survey. Significant outlet drop, especially at lower flows. Nice stream, likely a bull trout system. Several big boulders in outlet pool. Steep system. Fish (~60mm) observed during habitat confirmation.

assessment_comment: Long culvert which passed under the CN railway and a dirt road. A beaver dam located 50m downstream of the outlet created a larger beaver pond which was backwatering the culvert . Below the beaver dam, the stream had low gradients and provided good fish habitat. A gate across the inlet functioned as a beaver grate. The stream was fenced perpendicular to the channel both upstream and downstream, likely for cattle management. Signs of cattle accessing the stream were observed near the outlet.
condition_notes: A gate across the inlet was installed to prevent beaver entry and did not impede fish passage. No erosion or road fill issues were observed.
climate_notes: A flood was unlikely to affect the culvert, but if it did, it could wash out the railway.
priority_notes: Railways crossing so expensive and difficult. Fish points upstream.

assessment_comments_og: Gate across inlet acting as a beaver grate. Lots of beaver activation. Downstream of culvert is a big beaver pond which is back watering the culvert. Beaver dam 50m downstream of the outlet. Super nice Nice stream after the beaver dam, low gradients. Stream is fenced perpendicular to the stream, both upstream and downstream, due to someone cattle land. Signs of cattle accessing stream near outlet.

assessment_comment: A small wooden bridge crossed Teepee Creek on private land.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Small bridge over stream, most likely put it by adjacent landowner.

assessment_comment: A moderate outlet drop was present and would be substantial at lower flows. Flow was steady at the time of assessment. The culvert was in good condition. A large, deep outlet pool indicated the culvert was likely undersized for the stream. Additionally, minimal road fill made this crossing a significant flood hazard, which could wash out Highway 5. Downstream, the stream had frequent pools 0.3–0.5m deep, providing good overwintering habitat for fish, and abundant gravels suitable for spawning. Roughly 150m downstream of the culvert, several cattle pens crossed the stream and appeared to be set up to provide cattle access for drinking. These areas were visibly trampled, with significant loss of riparian vegetation. Upstream, the stream was relatively confined, with only rare pockets of unembedded gravels. Deep pools were present, formed by boulder and large woody debris scour. A salmon point was noted near the pipeline location in FISS. Numerous small steps, ranging from 30–60cm, were present due to the steep, boulder-dominated nature of the stream. Electrofishing would be beneficial for further assessment. The site was a highway crossing, making replacement difficult. A small ford was located approximately 5m downstream of the culvert outlet.
condition_notes: No blockage or road fill issues were present. Some erosion was observed under the outlet of the pipe, likely due to it being undersized for the stream.
climate_notes: The pipe was significantly undersized for the stream, and minimal road fill made this crossing a flood hazard. As a highway crossing, a flood could wash out the road.
priority_notes: Fish bearing stream with salmon point upstream. High priority to get fixed. Highway crossing so expensive. This crossing is also at high risk of flooding the highway so it should definitely get fixed.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Culvert is in good shape. Big deep outlet pool indicating the culvert is likely undersized for the size of the stream. Decent outlet drop at lower flows. Decent flow at time of survey. Really nice habitat downstream, lots of pools for overwintering fish and gravels for spawning. Frequent functional large woody debris creating complex habitat. Would highly recommend following up with electrofishing.hwy crossing so difficult. Small ford roughly 5m downstream of the culver outlet.

assessment_comment: A significant outlet drop was present. The pipe was in good condition, but there was erosion under the outlet and on the road column on the outlet side. The stream provided high-quality habitat with known fish in the system, including a salmon point downstream. The gradient was steep at this crossing, but the downstream highway crossing had lower gradients with abundant gravels. The road was a small dirt road with minimal road fill, making replacement relatively straightforward.
condition_notes: No blockage issues were present. Erosion was observed under and around the pipe outlet. The crossing had only 0.5m of road fill.
climate_notes: The culvert was undersized for the stream, and minimal road fill made it highly susceptible to washout during a flood. The road was a small dirt road, so a washout would not be a significant issue.
priority_notes: Low traffic dirt road and not much road fill so construction would be quite straight forward. Known fish bearing stream with salmon point downstream.
link_method_phase1: Link to Methods for Fish Passage Assessment
assessment_comments_og: Significant outlet drop. Pipe is in good condition but erosion under pipe outlet and road column on outlet side. Super nice stream with known fish in the system, salmon point downstream. Steep gradients at this crossing but crossing downstream on highway has low gradients and lots of nice gravels. Small dirt road with not much fill so replacement would be quite straight forward.

assessment_comment: Three concrete pipes, each 0.9m in diameter, were present, along with two 0.9m corrugated overflow pipes above. A stamp on the structure indicated it was built in 1944. All three concrete pipes were clogged at the inlet, ranging from 80% to 100% clogged with debris. This was a known fish-bearing stream, with a salmon point documented ~100m downstream in the FISS database. At this location, the stream was a mid-sized, steeper cobble-boulder step-pool system with only rare pockets of unembedded gravels. Deep pools were present, formed by boulder and large woody debris scour. Numerous small steps, ranging from 30–60cm, were present due to the steep, boulder-dominated nature of the stream. Downstream of the highway crossing, the stream had a lower gradient with frequent pools 0.3–0.5m deep, providing good overwintering habitat for fish and abundant gravels suitable for spawning.
condition_notes: All three inlets for the concrete pipes were clogged with debris, ranging from 80% to 100% clogged. The railway ballast was in good shape.
climate_notes: The railway installed two overflow pipes above the three concrete pipes to manage high-flow events. With the railway ballast composed of large angular cobble, a flood event seemed unlikely, provided the crossing was maintained. Downstream, residences were present before the highway, followed by additional private residences further below. A blowout at this location could have downstream impacts at the highway.
priority_notes: On the railway, so potentially very difficult to replace the crossing without interrupting transport services to severely. Apparently opportunity costs of closing the railway are very high, which leads apparently to very little addressing of environmental issues by this private corporation.

assessment_comments_og: Three cocrete pipes at 0.9m each with two corrugated overflows above at 0.9m each. Stamp on structure is 1944. All three concrete pipes are clogged at the inlet ranging from 80% to 100% clogged with debris.
